Word Closure-Based Metamorphic Testing for Machine Translation

Xiaoyuan Xie xxie@whu.edu.cn ,Â  Shuo Jin imjinshuo@whu.edu.cn School of Computer Science, Wuhan UniversityChina ,Â  Songqiang Chen i9s.chen@connect.ust.hk Â andÂ  Shing-Chi Cheung scc@cse.ust.hk Department of Computer Science and Engineering, The Hong Kong University of Science and TechnologyChina
(2024)
Abstract.

With the wide application of machine translation, the testing of Machine Translation Systems (MTSs) has attracted much attention. Recent works apply Metamorphic Testing (MT) to address the oracle problem in MTS testing. Existing MT methods for MTS generally follow the workflow of input transformation and output relation comparison, which generates a follow-up input sentence by mutating the source input and compares the source and follow-up output translations to detect translation errors, respectively. These methods use various input transformations to generate the test case pairs and have successfully triggered numerous translation errors. However, they have limitations in performing fine-grained and rigorous output relation comparison and thus may report many false alarms and miss many true errors. In this paper, we propose a word closure-based output comparison method to address the limitations of the existing MTS MT methods. We first propose word closure as a new comparison unit, where each closure includes a group of correlated input and output words in the test case pair. Word closures suggest the linkages between the appropriate fragment in the source output translation and its counterpart in the follow-up output for comparison. Next, we compare the semantics on the level of word closure to identify the translation errors. In this way, we perform a fine-grained and rigorous semantic comparison for the outputs and thus realize more effective violation identification. We evaluate our method with the test cases generated by five existing input transformations and the translation outputs from three popular MTSs. Results show that our method significantly outperforms the existing works in violation identification by improving the precision and recall and achieving an average increase of 29.9% in F1 score. It also helps to increase the F1 score of translation error localization by 35.9%.

Machine translation, Metamorphic testing, Word closure, Deep learning testing

1. Introduction

Machine translation systems (MTSs) have seen more and more applications in our daily life. Many popular MTSs, such as Google Translate and Bing Microsoft Translator, are providing translation services for millions of users every dayÂ (Shankland, 2013; Clayton, 2013). However, the automatically generated translations are not always correct. If not recognized, the incorrect translations provided by MTS can lead to significant issues, such as political conflictsÂ (Macdonald, 2015), false arrestÂ (Post, 2012; Davies, 2017), financial lossÂ (Vidhayasai etÂ al., 2015; Okrent, 2016), and vaccine mishapÂ (Bell, 2021). In order to avoid these problems, there have been a few testing methods proposed for MTS to detect its potential mistranslations.

One promising idea to efficiently test MTS is to apply Metamorphic Testing (MT) (Chen etÂ al., 1998). Some early methods adopt the round-trip translation to construct follow-up cases (Somers, 2005; Koehn and Monz, 2006; Shigenobu, 2007; Cao etÂ al., 2022). Recently, a few new methods propose more sophisticated Metamorphic Relations (MRs) that manipulate particular components of an input sentence to generate follow-up cases (He etÂ al., 2020, 2021; Gupta etÂ al., 2020; Sun etÂ al., 2022; Ji etÂ al., 2021). In the output comparison, these new methods check whether there are cases where the same (or different) input word is translated into different (or similar) meanings. If yes, there is a violation being reported, indicating at least one translation error. These new methods include SIT (He etÂ al., 2020), CAT (Sun etÂ al., 2022), Purity (He etÂ al., 2021), CIT (Ji etÂ al., 2021) and PatInv (Gupta etÂ al., 2020). Test cases generated by the input transformations in these five methods successfully trigger numerous mistranslations of MTS.

However, these methods still have several limitations regarding â€œwhat to compareâ€ and â€œhow to compareâ€. In terms of â€œwhat to compareâ€, we identified three major limitations: (1) Some methods cannot compare two output translations at a fine granularity for precise comparison. Specifically, SIT and CAT detect the violation according to the similarity between the entire (estimated) unchanged part of the two translations. However, such an overall similarity can not effectively reflect the fine-grained differences between the translations. As a result, violations can be incorrectly revealed on some correct translations while some translation errors can be missed. For instance, our experiments conducted on the English-to-Chinese translation service of Google Translate show that 48.0% and 40.6% of false alarms and 41.2% and 100.0% of missing detections in SIT and CAT can be attributed to this limitation. (2) Some methods lack the linkage between the fragment in the source output and its counterpart in the follow-up output to implement rigorous comparison. Specifically, without such linkages, Purity and CIT have to adopt relatively loose comparison strategies to judge the correctness of outputs, which may miss many translation errors. For example, we have found that 42.9% and 31.7% of missing detections in English-to-Chinese translations from Google Translate can be due to this limitation for Purity and CIT, respectively. (3) Some method (i.e., PatInv) ignores to detect the incorrect translations of the unchanged input words, which may also miss many translation errors. Take the testing of the English-to-Chinese translation from Google Translate as an example, all the violations missed by PatInv can be attributed to this limitation according to our experiment. In terms of â€œhow to compareâ€, we summarized two limitations: (1) Some methods that apply structure-based comparison methods fail to detect the incorrect translation that has the same structure but incorrect semantic meanings as its counterpart. Based on our experiment, when testing Google Translate to translate English into Chinese, this limitation causes 52.9% and 68.3% of missing detections for SIT and CIT, respectively. (2) Some methods adopt text-based comparison methods and thus cannot recognize the synonyms between the two translations. For example, in our experiment on the English-to-Chinese translations of Google Translate, we found that 72.5% and 88.2% of false alarms for CAT and Purity, respectively, can be attributed to this limitation. Thus, these limitations are pervasive and largely hinder the effectiveness of current methods.

Meanwhile, it is challenging to address the aforementioned limitations and achieve rigorous output violation checking. Specifically, it is necessary to link the fine-grained counterparts in the source and follow-up translations, which will be the proper comparison subjects against the metamorphic relation. To achieve a fine-grained violation identification, the native grammar unit, such as clause, phrase or word, is not suitable to work as the counterparts since they are not flexible and hard to match. Besides, to achieve a rigorous comparison, building linkages between these counterparts is challenging due to the poor performance of word-level alignment tools.

In this work, we propose to perform MT for MTS based on a new concept called word closure to alleviate the limitations in the existing output comparison methods. We first rule out the coarse comparison on the overall similarity of the outputs. The core idea of our solution is to link each appropriate fragment in the source output and its counterpart in the follow-up output (i.e. to construct word closures), such that a finer-grained and rigorous comparison can be realized. In this way, we can properly address the limitations of â€œwhat to compareâ€. Regarding the limitations of â€œhow to compareâ€, we compare the translations by evaluating their semantics to address the limitations of the structure- and text-based methods. With the help of word closure and semantic comparison, we can detect many missed errors (i.e. false negatives) and incorrectly detected errors (i.e. false positives) in existing works. In addition, the merit of â€œfine granularityâ€ enables our method to locate the fine-grained violations more precisely, i.e., the specific words that cause the overall violation within the test case pair.

We perform a comprehensive evaluation of our proposed output comparison approach to detect translation errors from three popular MTSs. The experiment results show that our approach can effectively reduce the false negatives and false positives in the existing methods, and lead to a significant improvement in the overall performance. Specifically, the average increase in F1 score is as high as 29.9% as compared with the five existing methods. For fine-grained violation locating, our approach outperforms the existing methods with an average increase in F1 score of 35.9%, which demonstrates the advantage of our method in locating the specific words that cause the overall violation within the test case pair.

To summarize, this paper addresses the limitations of violation identification methods applied by the existing MT testing works for MTS to achieve better performance in translation error detection. Our contributions are outlined below:

  • â€¢

    We review the latest MTS metamorphic testing works whose MRs mutate the source input sentence, summarize the primary limitations in their output relation comparison methods, and show the impact of such limitations on the error detection performance.

  • â€¢

    We propose a word closure-based output comparison method to alleviate the limitations of existing works in violation identification. Our approach can link each appropriate fragment in the source output and its counterpart in the follow-up output (i.e. to construct word closures), such that a finer-grained and rigorous comparison can be realized. Combined with semantic comparison, our method can properly resolve the problems of â€œwhat to compareâ€ and â€œhow to compareâ€.

  • â€¢

    The built linkages between the fragments in the source translation and their counterparts in the follow-up translation via word closure can further support the fine-grained violation localization, which can pinpoint the specific words giving rise to the detected violations.

  • â€¢

    The experiment results show that our word closure-based comparison method is very effective in reducing the false positives and false negatives in existing methods in both the widely-studied English-Chinese translation and the unexplored essential Chinese-English translation scenarios, and hence leads to a significant improvement in the overall violation detection ability. Specifically, our method achieves an average increase of 29.9% in the F1 score as compared with existing methods. In terms of locating fine-grained violations, our approach achieves an average increase of 35.9% in F1 score than the existing methods.

The dataset, replication package, and supplementary materials for this paper are available online at (DAT, 2023).

The remaining paper is organized as follows. In SectionÂ 2, we review the five target latest MT methods for MTS testing. SectionÂ 3 summarizes the limitations of existing work and illustrates specific examples, which motivate our work. In SectionÂ 4, we introduce our word closure-based output comparison approach and explain its detailed implementations. SectionÂ 5 lists the experimental setup and SectionÂ 6 presents the experiment results and analysis for the research questions. In SectionÂ 7, we study the helpfulness of our approach in enhancing the robustness of the machine translation model, summarize the limitations of our approach and outline some potential directions for future advancements. SectionÂ 8 discusses the threats to validity of this work, and SectionÂ 9 overviews the related works. Finally, we conclude the paper in SectionÂ 10.

2. Background

Recent automated MTS testing methodsÂ (Somers, 2005; Koehn and Monz, 2006; Shigenobu, 2007; Cao etÂ al., 2022; Zhou and Sun, 2018; He etÂ al., 2020, 2021; Gupta etÂ al., 2020; Sun etÂ al., 2020, 2022; Ji etÂ al., 2021) are mostly based on Metamorphic Testing (MT). MT solves the oracle problem of MTS testing via Metamorphic Relations (MRs), which describe the necessary properties of MTS in relation to multiple inputs and their expected outputs (Chen etÂ al., 2018). The violation of the MRs indicates the incorrect translation of MTS. Some early proposed methods test MTS via round-trip translation (Somers, 2005; Koehn and Monz, 2006; Shigenobu, 2007; Cao etÂ al., 2022). Recently, some new methods focus on MRs that manipulate particular components of an input sentence (Zhou and Sun, 2018; He etÂ al., 2020, 2021; Gupta etÂ al., 2020; Sun etÂ al., 2020, 2022; Ji etÂ al., 2021). Specifically, these MRs consist of two primary steps to test MTS, i.e., the input transformation (denoted as IT) and the output relation comparison (denoted as OR). Given a source input sentence (denoted as Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), the testing method transforms Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT into a new follow-up input sentence (denoted as Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) according to the input transformation of the MR. Next, the translations of both Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, denoted as Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively, are derived by running MTS with Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Finally, Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are compared to check if Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT violate the expected output relation defined by the MR. If a violation is identified, there should be translation errors within Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In this paper, we propose an approach to effectively enhance the MTS testing methods that transform the input sentence, which are more popular recently.

In the family of MT-based MTS testing methods that transforms the input sentence, five recent methods, i.e., SITÂ (He etÂ al., 2020), PatInvÂ (Gupta etÂ al., 2020), PurityÂ (He etÂ al., 2021), CITÂ (Ji etÂ al., 2021), and CATÂ (Sun etÂ al., 2022), have demonstrated outstanding performance in detecting incorrect translations of MTS. In the following, we introduce the MRs of these methods:

  1. (1)

    SIT: SIT is based on the MR that the translations of similar sentences should exhibit similar sentence structure. It replaces one word in Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with another word that keeps the same part of speech to generate a similar follow-up sentence Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We denoted this input transformation as IT-1. Next, SIT compares whether the constituency parse tree or dependency parse tree of two output translations Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are similar. This output relation is denoted as OR-1. If the distance between the two parse trees exceeds the predefined threshold, it reports this pair of test cases as a violation.

  2. (2)

    CAT: CAT employs the MR that the translations of two sentences with one different word should be similar except for those of the different words. CAT replaces one word in Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with another word similar in semantics to generate the Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (IT-2). To check whether the two input sentences are translated similarly except for the replaced words (OR-2), CAT leverages a strategy to roughly remove the translations of the replaced words from comparison and calculates the similarity score between the estimated unchanged part of the two translations. If the overall similarity score is below the predefined threshold, CAT reports a violation as the translations of the same input words are largely different.

  3. (3)

    Purity: Purity is based on the MR that a noun phrase should be translated similarly in different contexts. Purity proposes the input transformation to extract a noun phrase from Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the follow-up input Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (IT-3). To check whether the extracted noun phrase is translated similarly in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (OR-3), Purity measures how many word occurrences are in Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT but not in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the distance between the source and follow-up translations of the identical noun phrase. If the distance is above the threshold, Purity considers that the target noun phrase is translated differently in Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and reports this test case pair as a violation.

  4. (4)

    CIT: The MR of CIT is that the constituency structure of a sentenceâ€™s translation should remain unchanged if an adjunct, optional constituent of a sentence, is inserted in the sentence. The input transformation proposed by CIT is to add an adjunct into Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to generate the Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (IT-4). Given an original sentence, CIT leverages the sentence compression tool, which can automatically compress a sentence by removing all the adjuncts from it, to identify the adjuncts in the sentence. With the compressed sentence as Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, CIT adds one identified adjunct to generate the Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. To verify whether the constituency structure of Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT remains unchanged in Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (OR-4), CIT checks whether all the paths in the constituency parse tree of Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT exist in that of Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. CIT will report a violation if any path violates the above expected output relation.

  5. (5)

    PatInv: PatInv generates sentences with different meanings to detect translation errors. The MR of PatInv is that sentences with different meanings should have different translations. PatInv proposes two implementations to change the meaning of the source input sentence Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to generate the Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (IT-5). The first method is to replace one word in Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with a word of different semantics. Another one is to remove a meaningful word or phrase from Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. As Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT have different meanings, their translations Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are supposed to be different (OR-5). If Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are the same, PatInv will report a violation.

As shown in TableÂ 1, the five testing methods for MTS can be divided into categories according to their output comparison strategies and input transformations. Based on the output comparison strategy, the five testing methods are divided into two general categories, i.e., â€œEquivalence comparisonâ€ (Class-A and Class-B) including SIT, CAT, Purity, and CIT, and â€˜Unequivalence comparisonâ€ (Class-C) including PatInv. Within â€œEquivalence comparisonâ€, the four methods can be further divided into two sub-categories according to their input transformations. SIT and CAT are included in â€œWord replacementâ€ (Class-A). They both replace one word in the source input sentence to generate a similar follow-up input sentence. Although Purity and CIT apply two seemingly different input transformations, i.e., decremental and incremental transformations, they both build a pair of input sentences with different lengths, wherein the shorter sentence is a part of the longer one. Thus, we categorize them together as Class-B. For clarity, we summarize the output relation comparison method of these three categories in the last column of TableÂ 1.

Besides, the five testing methods can also be categorized based on their strategies in evaluating the similarity (or dissimilarity) between the output translations. Specifically, SIT and CIT use â€œstructure-based comparisonâ€ and CAT, Purity, and PatInv use â€œtext-based comparisonâ€.

However, all these categories of MTS testing methods have limitations in their output comparison methods. Such limitations will be discussed in SectionÂ 3.

3. Motivation

The five metamorphic testing methods for MTS have successfully detected mistranslations of MTS with their input transformations and output relations. However, the identified mistranslations based on MR violation can be wrong due to the limitations of their output relation comparison methods. The wrong identification results can be categorized into False Negatives (FNs) and False Positives (FPs). An FP means a pair of test cases, whose outputs satisfy the expected output relation of MR, is misidentified as a violation. Conversely, if a true violation is missed, an FN will be counted. In the following, we illustrate each limitation with practical examples 111For more detailed explanations of the examples (e.g., Chinese meanings), please refer to our online artifactÂ (DAT, 2023)..

  1. (1)

    Comparison methods of Class-A cannot compare two output translations at a fine granularity for precise comparison. SIT and CAT compare the overall sentence similarity between the entire (estimated) unchanged part of Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to detect the violation. Specifically, SIT checks whether the two sentences are translated similarly by computing the distance between the entire Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the entire Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Meanwhile, although CAT approximately removes the translations of the mutated words from the comparison, it computes the overall similarity score between the estimated unchanged part of translations in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to detect the violation. If the overall distance or similarity cannot satisfy the preset threshold, they regard this pair of test cases as a violation. However, such a coarse comparison strategy will inevitably introduce some FPs or FNs. On one hand, they can miss some finer violations, which do not lead to an obvious decrease in the overall similarity between Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This will lead to FNs. An FN example of SIT is shown in Fig.Â 1. SIT generates Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by replacing the word â€œtreasureâ€ in Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with â€œinteriorâ€, as marked in bold. In the translations Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, there is a redundant translation â€œç¾å›½â€ (the U.S.) in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the same input words â€œtaking down listingâ€ in Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are translated as different meanings in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., â€œä¸‹æ¶â€ (removed from shelves) and â€œåˆ é™¤æ¸…å•â€ (delete list). Therefore, this example is indeed a violation. However, due to the small difference introduced by the above translation error, the overall distance score between the parse trees of Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is lower than the threshold defined by SIT. As a result, the output translations for this test case pair are identified as non-violation by SIT. Similar FN cases can be found in CAT as well. On the other hand, coarse-grained comparison may misidentify the test cases that satisfy the output relation as a violation, which leads to FPs. An FP example of CAT is shown in Fig.Â 1. CAT generates Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by replacing the word â€œMondayâ€ in Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with â€œSundayâ€, as marked in bold. Although the translation of the adverbial clause â€œwhen everything is readyâ€ is placed at different positions in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as highlighted in blue, there is no violation within Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as they share similar meaningsÂ (Svenonius, 2002). However, CAT misidentifies it as a violation due to the overall low similarity between Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caused by the different positions of the adverbial clause. Similar FPs can also be found in SIT.

  2. (2)

    Comparison methods of Class-B lack the linkage between the fragment in the source output and its counterpart in the follow-up output to implement rigorous comparison. Given a sentence to translate, Purity and CIT generate a new input sentence by adding or deleting contents. Unlike Class-A methods that use the overall similarity to detect the translation errors for two relatively similar input sentences, Purity and CIT judge the inclusion relationship between the outputs for a pair of inputs. Specifically, they check whether the words or syntax parse tree paths of the shorter translation exist in that of the longer one token by token. However, this inclusion relationship checking method is relatively loose. It can lead to FNs in some cases when the shorter translation misses some necessary content or the longer translation contains redundant content. An FN example of CIT is shown in Fig.Â 1. CIT generates Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by inserting the adjunct â€œTherefore,â€ into Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as marked in bold. Because the same input word â€œassortedâ€ is translated as â€œä»€é”¦â€ in Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT but missed in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, there is a violation over this test case pair. However, CIT identifies this test case pair as non-violation because the constituency parse tree of Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT includes every path in the constituency parse tree of Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. As a result, lacking the linkages between the counterparts between Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, CIT implements a relatively loose comparison strategy and fails to detect the violation in this example. Similar FNs can be found in Purity as well.

  3. (3)

    Comparison method of Class-C ignores to detect the incorrect translations of the unchanged input words. PatInv only compares whether the altered words in Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are translated differently while ignoring the correctness of the other translations. As a result, PatInv fails to detect the incorrect translations in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the same input words, which leads to FNs. An FN example of PatInv is shown in Fig.Â 1. PatInv generates Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by replacing the word â€œpandemicâ€ in Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with â€œholidayâ€, as marked in bold. Although the same input word â€œpoliciesâ€ is translated as different meanings in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., â€œä¿å•â€ (guarantee slip) and â€œæ”¿ç­–â€ (policies), according to its output checking rule, PatInv regards this example as non-violation just because Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are different.

As a reminder, apart from the limitations from the above â€œwhat to compareâ€ aspect, current solutions to â€œhow to compareâ€ also have problems.

First, the structured-based comparison methods fail to detect the incorrect translation that has the same structure as its counterpart. Incorrect translation within Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT do not always lead to the different structures between Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Therefore, structured-based comparison methods can miss many incorrect translations, leading to FNs.

Secondly, the text-based comparison methods cannot recognize the synonyms between the two translations. Text-based comparison methods, which adopt string-based metrics (e.g. BLEU), measure the similarity between two translations based on the plain lexicographic match without considering meaningÂ (Colombo etÂ al., 2022). As a result, CAT and Purity can misidentify the synonyms within Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as violations, leading to FPs. For PatInv, which reports a violation only if the two translations are the same, the test case pairs with violations may be ignored due to the differences involved by synonyms, leading to FNs. To illustrate the limitation of the text-based comparison methods, we present an FP example of Purity in Fig.Â 1. Purity extracts a noun phrase from Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Although there are many synonyms between Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, e.g., â€œè€ƒè¯•â€ (tests) in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and â€œæµ‹è¯•â€ (tests) in Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, there is no violation between Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT because these synonyms share similar semantic meanings. Unable to recognize these synonyms, Purity misidentifies this example as a violation because four words from Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can not be found in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the sum of which is above the threshold.

To summarize, every existing output comparison method has at least two of the above limitations, from the aspects of both â€œwhat to compareâ€ and â€œhow to compareâ€. These limitations, as summarized in TableÂ 2, may lead to FPs, FNs, or both and therefore degrade the testing method performance. On one hand, reporting many FPs reduces the reliability of the test results and requires additional manual filtering to identify true translation errors. On the other hand, some serious translation errors within the FNs may be undetected and unfixed, posing potential risks to the practical application of MTS. Furthermore, too many FNs may even mislead users into believing that the quality of MTS is dependable and using MTS without hesitation in some key areas. In order to achieve more adequate violation identification, in this work, we propose a word-closure-based output comparison method to address the aforementioned limitations.

4. Methodology

4.1. Core Idea and Approach Overview

In this work, we propose a new output relation comparison approach for Metamorphic Testing of Machine Translation. It addresses the limitations regarding â€œwhat to compareâ€ and â€œhow to compareâ€ of the output checking method in existing methods introduced in SectionÂ 3. It realizes more rigorous output checking and can be used with existing input transformation methods.

First, to address the limitations from â€œwhat to compareâ€, we propose a new type of granularity, namely â€œword closureâ€. We perform output comparisons on this granularity level. As mentioned in SectionÂ 3, it is too coarse to compare the source and follow-up outputs by measuring the overall similarity between translations. A finer-grained entity is needed for comparison. Meanwhile, simply adopting native grammar units such as words, phrases, or clauses cannot meet the requirement in our MT scenario. The main reason is that, in MT, test cases are changed via various transformations. As a result, we usually need to compare a particular fragment in the source output and its counterpart in the follow-up output against some relations (i.e. MRs). In other words, the core challenge during this process is to identify the corresponding relation between a particular fragment in the source output and its counterpart in the follow-up output. Comparisons against MRs should be performed by referring to these relations. Simply adopting the native grammar units cannot achieve this goal, as these units across the source and follow-up outputs do not always show explicit corresponding relations. In this work, we propose â€œword closureâ€ to address the above challenge. A word closure comprises the appropriate counterparts in a pair of source and follow-up outputs, which are linked for comparison against the output relation, as well as their corresponding fragments in the source and follow-up inputs. SectionÂ 4.2 will explain the details of word closure.

To construct the word closures, word mappings between the input sentences and output translations are necessary. It is not difficult to think of adopting a general word alignment tool, which is also mentioned in (He etÂ al., 2021; Sun etÂ al., 2020). However, the accuracy of basic word alignments does not meet our requirements. Thus, we propose two algorithms to refine the word alignment results, which are described in SectionÂ 4.3. After the construction of all word closures for a pair of metamorphic test cases, comparisons against the MR will be performed between the translation fragments linked by word closures.

The idea of performing comparison within the linked counterparts in the source and follow-up outputs based on word closures allows us to address the limitations of Class-A, Class-B, and Class-C. Firstly, we use word closure to split the translations into finer granularity, which is shorter than the comparison unit of entire translations adopted by Class-A. This helps to avoid the FPs and FNs introduced by a coarse comparison granularity. Secondly, word closures can link each fragment from Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with its counterpart in Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This enables a more rigorous comparison by clearly identifying the elements to compare, which cannot be realized by Class-B. In addition, Class-C only compares the translations of changed words. Meanwhile, word closures can be utilized to compare the translations of both the same input words and the changed input words to detect the incorrect translations more adequately.

By considering the limitations from â€œhow to compareâ€, we propose to compare the semantic similarity (or dissimilarity if needed) of the translations to detect violations. On one hand, comparing the semantic similarity can expose the violations with different meanings but identical structures, which are ignored by the structure-based comparison methods. On the other hand, semantic-based comparison can identify the synonyms within the source and follow-up translations due to their similar semantics, thereby avoiding the FPs and FNs caused by the text-based comparison methods. When comparing translations of the same input words, we detect violations based on their semantic similarity. For the translations of the changed input words, we check their semantic dissimilarity (similarity) if the changed input words have different (similar) meanings. As a reminder, in our approach, we compare the semantic similarity at a fine granularity, i.e., word closure. By properly addressing the limitations about â€œwhat to compareâ€, the semantic comparison can be performed more accurately.

TableÂ 3 briefly summarizes how our method addresses each limitation of the existing output comparison methods for MTS testing.

Fig.Â 2 presents an overview of our approach. The input comprises a pair of source and follow-up input sentences Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT generated through the input transformation of MRs, as well as their translations Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (i.e., source and follow-up outputs) returned by MTS. To detect whether MTS violates the MR on the test case pair, our approach involves two modules for constructing word closures from the test case pair and one module for detecting the violation by evaluating the semantics of the translation counterparts linked by word closures. The construction of word closure requires the word mappings between input sentences and output translations. Thus, in the first module â€œRefined Word Alignmentâ€, we adopt the word alignment tool and propose two refinement algorithms to build the word alignment between Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) and Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). Next, in the second module â€œWord Closure Constructionâ€, we construct all the word closures from the input test cases to match the finer granularity between the two translations. Finally, in the last module â€œTranslation Comparisonâ€, we compare the semantics of the translation fragments matched by the constructed word closures to detect the violations. The detected violations are returned as the output. In the following, we will illustrate the definition of word closure, the implementation of the three modules, and the finalized metamorphic relation of our approach.

4.2. Word Closure

Before we formally define word closure, we want to show the problems of using native grammar units for comparison. Fig.Â 3 uses the example of PatInv-FN shown in Fig.Â 1, where the follow-up input sentence Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is generated by replacing the word â€œpandemicâ€ in Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as â€œholidayâ€. In contrast to PatInv which only requires two outputs to be different, a more reasonable comparison should check whether the same input words are translated similarly and the different input words are translated dissimilarly in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. However, to achieve this goal, the first necessary step is to link the counterparts in the source and follow-up outputs. Now, let us consider the naive method that adopts native grammar units of clauses, phrases, and words represented by the boxes in Fig.Â 3. We identify two problems that motivate us to design a proper granularity for comparison.

The constituency parse tree represents the clause and phrase structures in a sentence. According to the constituency parse tree of Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we extract the clauses and phrases of Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT respectively in Fig.Â 3. At the clause level, we can identify one clause in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and one clause in Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, both marked as â€œIPâ€ (simple clause). At the phrase level, we can identify five phrases in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and four phrases in Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, marked as â€œNPâ€ (noun phrase), â€œDNPâ€ (phrase ended with â€œçš„â€), â€œPPâ€ (preposition phrase), and â€œVPâ€(verb phrase). At the word level, a tokenizer is adopted to split Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT into tokens. The first problem is that the grammar units in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ \boldsymbol{T_{s}}bold_italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT do not have explicit linkage with their counterparts in Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“\boldsymbol{T_{f}}bold_italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This lack of linkage creates confusion when determining which units in Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT respectively should be compared against the MR, particularly for grammar units such as phrases and words that have multiple options. Simply comparing these grammar units between Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT one by one to detect their difference as the violation is unreasonable as Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are not supposed to be totally identical due to different input sentences. Another problem is that establishing the links between these grammar units is unpracticable in some cases. At the clause level, the two clauses in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are not the translation of the same input words and therefore should not be linked for comparison. At the phrase level, we can only establish a linkage between the noun phrases (highlighted in blue), i.e., â€œå¤§å¤šæ•° ä¿å•â€ in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and â€œå¤§å¤šæ•° æ”¿ç­–â€ in Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For other phrases, their corresponding input words overlap only partially, such as â€œ1Â æœˆä»½â€ (January) in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and â€œåœ¨Â ä¸€æœˆä»½â€ (In January) in Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, therefore should not be matched. At the word level, even though more units can match their counterparts in another translation (highlighted in blue), there are still many words that can not be linked as they correspond to different input words.

To address these problems, we propose the concept of â€œword closureâ€. Word closures provide a more appropriate granularity of comparison, meanwhile can intrinsically support establishing the necessary linkage between the fragment in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and its counterpart in Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for output relation checking. Word closure construction will be performed on the sets of words in Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively. As a reminder, identical words in the sets of source and follow-up cases should be treated as different objects in our method.

Words wssuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘ w^{s}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, wfsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘“w^{f}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, tssuperscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ t^{s}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and tfsuperscriptğ‘¡ğ‘“t^{f}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can be aggregated in the same word closure, iff these words have some correlation with one another, but are not correlated with words outside this closure. As a reminder, it is possible that one or more sets in this aggregation (but not all) are empty, and some words in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are not included in any closure (the detailed construction process will be introduced in SectionÂ 4.4).

By definition, a word closure is a minimal aggregation of linked words, and there is no overlapping among different closures. For example, the last row of Fig.Â 3 presents the word closures constructed from PatInv-FN. The dotted arrows in the word closures represent the correlations between the words within the input sentences and output translations. In the first word closure, the four words, i.e., â€œInâ€ from Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, â€œInâ€ from Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, â€œåœ¨â€ from Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and â€œåœ¨â€ from Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT have correlations with each other and no correlation with the words outside this closure. The other four closures also meet these properties, and there is no overlapping among different word closures. The solid arrows linking Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT signify the linkages constructed by word closures. It can be observed that word closure establishes the linkage between the fragment in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and its counterpart in Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, covering the majority of tokens in both translations. Therefore, compared with the native grammar granularities, word closure is more appropriate in identifying violations as the linkages built by word closure enable us to perform a fine-grained output comparison against the output relation.

In the next three sections, we will introduce how to construct word closures for a pair of metamorphic test cases and their outputs, as well as how to compare the outputs against the expected relations. Specifically, we need a refined word alignment to build the correlations between the input and output words, based on which we build closures.

4.3. Refined Word Alignment

The construction of word closure depends on the word alignment between the input sentences and output translations. However, the accuracy of current word alignment tools cannot meet our requirementsÂ (He etÂ al., 2021; Sun etÂ al., 2020): we found that current tools may overlook certain word alignments, resulting in many ineffective word closures that fail to indicate the correct linkage between the source and follow-up output counterparts. Thus, we first employ a word alignment tool to initially align the words in the input texts and output translations of the source and follow-up test cases respectively. Then, we match the words in the source and follow-up inputs, and next use two heuristic strategies to refine these missed alignments for better construction of word closures. Specifically, we first adopt a state-of-the-art word alignment tool, AWESOME, (Dou and Neubig, 2021) to build the basic word alignments between Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) and Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) and store them in a dictionary Mssubscriptğ‘€ğ‘ M_{s}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Mfsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘“M_{f}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). For each word wğ‘¤witalic_w in Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), AWESOME stores in Msâ¢[w]subscriptğ‘€ğ‘ delimited-[]ğ‘¤M_{s}[w]italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_w ] a set of words {w1,w2,â€¦}subscriptğ‘¤1subscriptğ‘¤2â€¦\{w_{1},w_{2},\ldots\}{ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ } in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) that are aligned with wğ‘¤witalic_w. Mfsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘“M_{f}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT functions similarly for Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We then align the unmutated input words in Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and store the mapping in the dictionary Misubscriptğ‘€ğ‘–M_{i}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT according to the input transformation. For each unmutated word wğ‘¤witalic_w in Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), Miâ¢[w]subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘¤M_{i}[w]italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_w ] returns its corresponding unmutated word {wâ€²}superscriptğ‘¤â€²\{w^{\prime}\}{ italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } in Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT); for each mutate word wâ€²superscriptğ‘¤â€²w^{\prime}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, Miâ¢[wâ€²]subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–delimited-[]superscriptğ‘¤â€²M_{i}[w^{\prime}]italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] returns an empty set. Next, we apply two strategies to refine the word alignments within Mssubscriptğ‘€ğ‘ M_{s}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Mfsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘“M_{f}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which are built by the word alignment tool.

Refinement strategy 1: The first strategy helps to recover the missed word alignments according to the constituency parse tree of the translation. If an input word is translated as multiple words in the target language, the multiple output words should be aligned with this input word. However, the word alignment tool may miss some of the alignments between them. Fig.Â 4 shows the alignments unrecognized by the word alignment tool for the example of PatInv-FN. In the example, the â€œJanuaryâ€ in the input sentence is translated as two Chinese words (â€1â€ and â€æœˆä»½â€), and the input word â€œpandemicâ€ is also translated as two Chinese words (â€œå¤§â€ and â€œæµè¡Œâ€). However, according to the basic word alignments from AWESOME, â€œJanuaryâ€ is only aligned with â€œ1â€ but without â€œæœˆä»½â€, and â€œpandemicâ€ is only aligned with â€œæµè¡Œâ€ but without â€œå¤§â€. In most cases, the multiple translated words corresponding to an input word are always in the same phrase in the translation and function as a whole unitÂ (Wikipedia, 2023b). Thus, our refinement strategy 1 is to align the words within the same phrase in the translation to identical input words. This strategy builds the missing alignments mentioned above, where the phrase structures are recognized based on the constituency parse tree of the translation. As a reminder, we do not consider verb phrases because they may contain too many modifiers to represent very complex semanticsÂ (Wikipedia, 2023c).

Refinement strategy 2: Our refinement strategy 2 is based on the idea that each unique output word that appears in both Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT should be aligned with the same input word. 4.4. Word Closure Construction

The construction process is illustrated in AlgorithmÂ 3. This process begins with adding one input word from either Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to act as the initial word of a new closure. Subsequently, we continually iterate through each word within the closure to add its correlated words within the test cases into the closure until no further new words can be added. At the very beginning, all words in Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are labeled as UNMARKED, which indicates they are not associated with no word closure (Lines 14-15).

4.5. Translation Comparison

The constructed word closures can be categorized into three types: Comparable Word Closure (CWC), Mutated Word Closure (MWC), and Unmatched Word Closure (UWC). Our output relation comparison is performed on these three types of word closures, respectively. CWC refers to the word closure that contains the same input words in Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as well as their corresponding translations in both Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Since the same input words should be translated similarly, we compare whether the translations within each CWC are similar in semantics. For detailed examples of CWC, please refer to the â€œcomparison for CWCsâ€ illustrated below. MWC is the closure that contains the mutated input word in Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, due to the MR transformation. If the mutated words are different in semantics according to the input transformation, we check whether their translations in MWC also have different semantics. Otherwise, we evaluate whether the translations in MWC have similar semantics. Specific examples of MWC can be found in the following description of the â€œcomparison for MWCsâ€. UWC refers to the word closure that contains the same input words in Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT but without their translations in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In other words, UWCs fail to show the linkages between the source and follow-up translations of the same input words. However, this does not necessarily indicate that the translations in UWCs are violations because the presence of UWCs could be attributed to the missed word alignments caused by the word alignment tool. If some word alignments are missed, the corresponding translations will not be included in word closures, resulting in UWCs. Detailed examples of UWC can be found in the following illustration of â€œ comparison for UWCsâ€. To determine if the same input words in UWCs are translated similarly, we perform a semantic similarity comparison between the translations contained within UWCs and those not included in any word closures. As a reminder, if the translations in a word closure are all stopwords, such as the ğ’1subscriptğ’1\mathcal{C}_{1}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Fig.Â 6, where the only translation â€œåœ¨â€ is a stopword, we exclude this word closure from the comparison, considering the negligible information carried by stopwordsÂ (Lo etÂ al., 2005).

Comparison for CWCs: Each CWC builds the linkage between a fragment in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and its counterpart in Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. To check whether the same input words in Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are translated similarly in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we perform the semantic similarity comparison for each CWC. Specifically, within a CWC, we evaluate the semantic similarity score between the words from Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the words from Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and report a violation if their similarity score is below the preset threshold. Take the CWC ğ’8subscriptğ’8\mathcal{C}_{8}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 8 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT depicted in Fig.Â 6 as example. We compute the semantic similarity between â€œç»´æŠ¤â€, â€œæˆæœ¬â€ in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and â€œç»´æŠ¤è´¹ç”¨â€ in Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and consider them to satisfy the output relation because their similarity score is above the preset threshold.

Comparison for MWCs: For MWC, which contains the mutated input words, we perform the semantic dissimilarity (similarity) comparison to check whether the mutated input words, which have different (similar) meanings, are translated dissimilarly (similarly). To note, the comparison over MWCs only applies when the transformation ensures that the original and mutated words should be translated similarly or differently. For example, among our five transformations, only IT-5 mutates the original words into another word with a different meaning. As such, we only perform the comparison for MWCs in the test cases generated by IT-5, checking whether the translations in MWCs are dissimilar in semantics. Among the word closures of PatInv-FN shown in Fig.Â 6, ğ’14subscriptğ’14\mathcal{C}_{14}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 14 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ’15subscriptğ’15\mathcal{C}_{15}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 15 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are MWCs because they contain the mutated input words â€œpandemicâ€ and â€œholidayâ€, which have different meanings. For MWCs, we cannot perform comparison within one closure due to the difficulty in aligning the mutated input words, which causes their translations to be scattered across different closures. Instead, we compare the relations across all the MWCs. Specifically, we collect the translations contained in all the MWCs and evaluate the semantic similarity score between the collected translations from Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. If the similarity score is above the preset similarity threshold, i.e., violating the requirement for different semantics, we will report a violation. So, in Fig.Â 6, we collect the translations from the two MWCs, i.e., â€œå¤§â€, â€œæµè¡Œâ€ and â€œå‡æœŸâ€, for comparison. Next, we compute the similarity score between â€œå¤§â€, â€œæµè¡Œâ€ from Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and â€œå‡æœŸâ€ from Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Ultimately, we consider them to have different semantics and detect no violation because their similarity score is below the preset threshold.

As a reminder, to support the above comparison practices for CWCs and MWCs, we can use different methods to calculate the similarity between word closures. In this work, we explore five comparison strategies. We suggest the optimal comparison strategy of referring to a synonym database and the language model embeddings. Detailed introduction to these comparison strategies can be found in SectionÂ 6.5.

Comparison for UWCs and all left-over non-stopwords: After the comparisons among CWCs and MWCs, we now need to process the comparison for all UWCs, as well as the left-over non-stopwords222Stopwords are not considered in the comparison. in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that are not included in any closures. Since UWC does not contain the translations from Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we can not perform the comparison in each UWC as we do in CWC. For this part, we use the following operations:

  • 1)

    Collect the non-stopword words in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that are included in UWCs or not included in any word closures and store them to two sets ğ•†ssubscriptğ•†ğ‘ \mathbb{O}_{s}blackboard_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ•†fsubscriptğ•†ğ‘“\mathbb{O}_{f}blackboard_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively.

  • 2)

    Pair each word in ğ•†ssubscriptğ•†ğ‘ \mathbb{O}_{s}blackboard_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and each word in ğ•†fsubscriptğ•†ğ‘“\mathbb{O}_{f}blackboard_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and calculate a total of |ğ•†s|Ã—|ğ•†f|subscriptğ•†ğ‘ subscriptğ•†ğ‘“|\mathbb{O}_{s}|\times|\mathbb{O}_{f}|| blackboard_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | Ã— | blackboard_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | semantic similarity scores.

  • 3)

    Sort these word pairs based on their similarity scores from high to low.

  • 4)

    Traverse the word pairs sequentially, and match the words that have a similarity score above the threshold and have not been matched before.

  • 5)

    Report the violation if there are words not matched in ğ•†ssubscriptğ•†ğ‘ \mathbb{O}_{s}blackboard_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or ğ•†fsubscriptğ•†ğ‘“\mathbb{O}_{f}blackboard_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

As all the UWCs of PatInv-FN shown in Fig.Â 6 contain no translations or only contain the stopwords, for better illustration, we use the example depicted in Fig.Â 7 to explain the above comparison steps. First, we collect the non-stopword translations in the UWCs, i.e. â€œç¾å›½â€ in ğ’3subscriptğ’3\mathcal{C}_{3}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and â€œæ¸…å•â€ in ğ’11subscriptğ’11\mathcal{C}_{11}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 11 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the non-stopword translations outside the closures, i.e., â€œå…¬å¸â€ in both Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Next, we calculate the semantic similarity score between each word in ğ•†ssubscriptğ•†ğ‘ \mathbb{O}_{s}blackboard_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:{ç¾å›½, å…¬å¸} and each word in ğ•†fsubscriptğ•†ğ‘“\mathbb{O}_{f}blackboard_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:{å…¬å¸, æ¸…å•}. After sorting the word pairs according to their similarity score, we match â€œå…¬å¸â€ from Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and â€œå…¬å¸â€ from Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as their similarity score (100%) is higher than the threshold. The similarity scores between the other word pairs are all below the threshold. As a result, we detect the violation of â€œç¾å›½â€ in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and â€œæ¸…å•â€ in Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as they are not semantically matched with the word in Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT respectively.

In the end, we collect all the violations detected through the above comparison processes for CWCs, MWCs and UWCs and return them as the violation identification results of our method.

4.6. Metamorphic Relation

As shown in Fig.Â 8, our proposed output relation can be integrated with diverse input transformations to formulate new metamorphic relations. The detailed metamorphic relations are presented in TableÂ 4. Given the source and follow-up input sentences generated by any of the five input transformations, our expected output relation is that the same words shared by the two inputs are translated as similar semantics and the changed input words with similar (different) meanings are translated as similar (dissimilar) semantics. If the same input words are translated dissimilarly or the changed input words of similar (different) meanings are translated dissimilarly (similarly), at least one of the output translations contains an error and our approach will report a violation.

4.7. Illustration on How Our Approach Addresses Limitations

In this section, we explain how our approach addresses the five limitations of the existing output comparison methods (discussed in SectionÂ 3), with illustrative examples.

4.7.1. For the limitation of Class-A

To mitigate this limitation, we propose word closure to achieve finer granularity comparison by building the linkages between the fragment in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and its counterpart in Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for output relation comparison. SIT-FN is a false negative of SIT caused by the limitation of Class-A. Fig.Â 7 shows how our approach detects the violation in SIT-FN with word closure. The input test cases violate the output relation because the same input words â€œtaking down listingâ€ in Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are translated as different meanings, i.e., â€œä¸‹æ¶â€ (removed from shelves) in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and â€œåˆ é™¤æ¸…å•â€ (delete list) in Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and there is a redundant word in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., â€œç¾å›½â€(the U.S.). However, SIT regards this example as non-violation because the overall distance score between the entire Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the entire Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is below the threshold. Different from the coarse comparison applied by SIT, our method constructs word closures, â„‚={ğ’1,ğ’2,ğ’3,â€¦,ğ’22}â„‚subscriptğ’1subscriptğ’2subscriptğ’3â€¦subscriptğ’22\mathbb{C}{=}\{\mathcal{C}_{1},\mathcal{C}_{2},\mathcal{C}_{3},\dots,\mathcal{% C}_{22}\}blackboard_C = { caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 22 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, from SIT-FN to build the fine-grained linkages between Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. CAT-FP is a false positive of CAT, also due to the limitation of Class-A. Fig.Â 9 shows how our approach resolves the CAT-FP with word closure. In the example, all the same input words in Sssubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ S_{s}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sfsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘“S_{f}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are translated similarly in Tssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ T_{s}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Tfsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘“T_{f}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.
